Global Warming and CO2 Emissions: A Data-Driven Story

The map shows us Annual CO₂ emissions by country, Per capita CO₂ emissions and Historical CO₂ emissions by country, which shows us the geographical distribution of these emissions. The chart on the left shows the corresponding data for several key countries in a specific year.

From the mid-18th century to the mid-19th century, with the development of the first industrial revolution, due to the vigorous development of steam technology and the rapid expansion of the number of factories, the UK's CO₂ emissions increased significantly, leading the world by far.

From the middle of the 19th century, the CO₂ emissions of the EU (27) and the United States began to increase. From the late 19th century to the early 20th century, with the outbreak of the Second Industrial Revolution and the widespread use of electricity, the CO₂ emissions of the EU (27) and the United States gradually approached and surpassed the United Kingdom. For a long time, the United States ranked first in the world in emissions, and per capita emissions have been ranked first in the world since the beginning of the 20th century.

Since the 20th century, CO₂ emissions have begun to rise around the world, especially in China, which has been increasing at a high rate since its founding and has become the country with the largest emissions in the 21st century.
